text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Junior finance minister amends tax proposal governing owner/directors of their own firms. (p1)
- TV production and entertainment company Endemol promises future shareholders doubling of profits in five years, mainly through foreign expansion. (p1)
- Amsterdam stock exchange chalks up new record closing high at 571.92 points. (p1)
- Property arm of banking group ING looking to participate in shopping mall Hoog Catharijne in Utrecht. (p3)
- Textiles group Braat Beheer posts first half 1996 net of Dfl 915,000 from Dfl 877,000 in same period of 1995. (p3)
- Temp workers win the right to join strikes. (p3)
- Rotterdam port authority wants to increase financial reserves to be able to finance new projects. (p3)
- Dutch tax authorities to pay back Dfl 650 million in excise duties to the wine trade, following a European Court of Justice ruling. (p5)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- Growing doubts about Liberal party leader Bolkestein's combination of functions as and MP and supervisory director of Merck Sharp & Dohme. (p1)
- Dutch businesses led by economic affairs minster Hans Wijers accompany Queen Beatrix on visit to South Africa. (p1)
- Food companies Hero and Suned International to build a joint soft drinks plant near Moscow. (p2)
DE TELEGRAAF
- PM Wim Kok has no objection to the introduction of road-pricing in 1998. (p3)
- Chief of ABN AMRO bank P.J. Kalff says the European single currency Euro will do little harm to Dutch banks. (p13)
- Long-term interst rate drops under six percent for first time since January. (p13)
TROUW
- ABN AMRO jeopardises shorter working week for banking sector. (p3)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Growing opposition to Hague plan for reclaiming land.
